Title:
Hopping Out of Mindanao: Pre-Pleistocene Cross-Island
Colonization as A Major Driver for Diversification of An Endemic
Treehopper in the Philippine Archipelago
Keywords:
Pleistocene islands, long-distance dispersal, cryptic
species, host plant adaptation, Pyrgonota bifoliata, Membracidae
Abstract:
Here we describe the first study performed on an endemic
treehopper, Pyrgonota bifoliata, to test the Pleistocene island
hypothesis, a paradigm for the process of diversification within the
Philippine Archipelago. This treehopper showed one of the lowest levels
of between-Pleistocene island genetic variation among all examined taxa,
representing by far the strongest empirical evidence that is
inconsistent with this paradigm. Contrary to most Philippine
vertebrates, the spatio-temporally calibrated phylogeny based on
mitochondrial and nuclear genes supported the notion that the
Miocene-Pliocene geological events and the consequent cross-island
dispersal were major drivers of diversity for P. bifoliata. Ancestral P.
bifoliata originated in the Late Miocene from Mindanao, followed by the
sequential northward colonisation of the Visayan islands and Luzon in
the Pliocene-Early Pleistocene, which coincided with the spatial
reorganisation and temporal sequence of dry-land formation of the
oceanic Philippines. The statistically delimited cryptic species
corresponded to current island boundaries and specialised host plants,
implying that both allopatric isolation and ecological adaptation may be
prominent promoters of speciation for these organisms. Our findings
suggest that the existing Pleistocene island model of Philippine
diversification is inadequate and requires modification through
incorporating pre-Pleistocene geological events, the colonisation
history of species, and within-island ecological processes.
